For release Sunday, Dec. 24
With BC-Eastern-Then and Now
Major Players in the Eastern Airlines Drama
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief profiles of some of the major players in the Eastern Airlines strike and bankruptcy proceeding, which began in early March: _FRANK LORENZO: Powerful chairman of Texas Air Corp., owner of Eastern and Continental Airlines, denounced as a ``robber baron'' by unions and considered an airline industry pioneer by some. _PHIL BAKES: President of Miami-based Eastern, reporting to Lorenzo. A former attorney for the Civil Aeronautics Board, he was influential in drawing up the 1978 law deregulating the U.S. airline industry. _CHARLES BRYAN: Leader of the Machinists union at Eastern, known before the strike for his fiery temper and fierce opposition to management, who adopted a low public profile after the walkout began. _JACK BAVIS: Former head of Eastern pilots union, thrown out by the membership in September for proposing that they consider ending their strike. He was replaced by Skip Copeland, a hard-liner on the strike. The pilots reversed their position shortly before Thanksgiving and voted to call off their walkout, which had been in sympathy with the Machinists' wage dispute. The Eastern flight attendants union, headed by MARY JANE BARRY, quickly followed suit. _BURTON R. LIFLAND: The U.S. bankruptcy judge overseeing Eastern's Chapter 11 proceeding that began March 9 in federal court in New York. A powerful judge known for biting sarcasm, he took an aggressive approach to his goal of getting Eastern flying again. _DAVID I. SHAPIRO: The special bankruptcy examiner appointed by Lifland to mediate between Eastern management and unions and to investigate the financial history of Eastern, its sister carrier Continental and their parent Texas Air. A street-smart Washington attorney, he has participated in cases ranging from prostitution to freedom of speech. _PETER V. UEBERROTH: Former baseball commissioner, who made a $464 million bid to buy Eastern from Lorenzo in April. He had extensive negotiations with Eastern's unions, which agreed to labor concessions in exchange for a 30 percent share in the airline. But the deal collapsed when the unions insisted on a trustee to replace Lorenzo before Ueberroth took over, and Lorenzo refused. _JOSEPH RITCHIE: Chicago businessman and quixotic bidder for Eastern, who made a bid in early May in alliance with the unions. Lifland removed the buyout plan from consideration and Lorenzo dismissed it as a ``joke''. _JOEL ZWEIBEL: Lead attorney for the committee representing Eastern's major unsecured creditors, such as aircraft manufacturers.
